column2: Followers of the Great Serpent build elaborate sanctuaries to honor their lord, not just as a show of devotion but as an arsenel to protect their people.
Many young soldiers spend their childhoods running up and down the Pass, training their agility and endurance. This training ground is designed in such a way to simulate that experience.
Although lacking the benders of other regions in the Earth Kingdom, rulers in the Serpent's Pass make up for it in their overwhelming numbers and naval expertise.
Guided tours across Serpent's Pass, generating extra income.

column1: Can only be built in the duchies containing the §GSerpent's Pass.§!

column2: The powerful unagi are another breed of Giant Eel, dotted around the world, with some even living within the vicinity of Kyoshi Island.
Tribal villages along the Serpent's Pass will often construct poorly held-together effigies of their lord.
Serpentine streetmarkets tend to wind around the city, weaving through alleyways and sometimes even buildings, with seemingly no beginning or end to the chain of stores.
More formal than a simple monument, Serpentine Shrines are houses of worship entirely dedicated to the Great Serpent, in all of its glory.
Any coastal province held by a weak Great Serpent worshipper can, by serpentine decree, be usurped by someone more fit to lead.
Inland provinces are little more than outposts, but can still be rightfully claimed from an incompetent Great Serpent ruler.
Coastal provinces in the hands of non-believers are ripe for the picking, to any serpentine ruler ambitious enough take them.
With a dominated coastline, a Great Serpent ruler may set their eyes inland, to reinforce their burgeoning empire.
